 BOLIVIA RURAL COMMUNITIES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 In recent years participatory grassroots projects have increasingly become the major thrust of Bolivia's rural development strategy. Experiences in the Mizque and Zudanes provinces, where NGOs have executed projects with high participatory content, have fostered project ownership by the beneficiary communities and investment sustainability. Government intends to replicate these experiences on a national scale. Within this context, it has since 1993 engaged in a decentralization effort allowing Municipalities to determine their political, financial, and developmental course. 1.2 Through a series of administrative reforms, such as the creation of the National Secretariat of Rural Development (Secretaria Nacional de Desarrollo Rural, SNDR) and the issuance of the Popular Participation Law (Ley de Participaci6n Popular, LPP), Government has started to tap the merits of local self-determination to promote development. As an initial step, SNDR has implemented a pilot project in nine selected provinces to test the participatory approach for rural development. This pilot operation has been financed by an IDA Project Preparation Facility and Japanese Trust Funds. The proposed project is based on the experience of the pilot project and other SNDR activities. 1.3 Project identification took place in December 1993. In February 1994, Government requested IDA support for the proposed project. Project preparation mnissions visited Bolivia in April and July 1994. Pre-appraisal took place in November 1994, appraisal in February 1995 and negotiations in June 1995. IFAD participated in the project's preparation and appraisal missions. COTESU (Swiss Technical Cooperation) participated in the project's pre-appraisal. Both organizations would participate in project implementation as financing partners. 2. BACKGROUND A. The Macro-Economic Situation 2.1 Faced with a severe economic crisis in de mid-1980s, Bolivia was one of the first countries in Latin America to adopt a far reaching economic program aimed at restoring price stability and restructuring the economy. The economic reform program combined comprehensive structural reforms with tight monetary policy and a program to reduce debt and debt service payments. This has resulted in restoring price stability and economic growth--real GDP growth has been an annual four percent in recent years. 2.2 Bolivia's economy remains fragile. The 1994 fiscal deficit--3.2 percent of GDP--was, however, significantly lower than the 1993 deficit. The external position remains weak--although the 12-month current account deficit (after official transfers)
 decreased to 5 percent of GDP in 1994. Moreover, Bolivia remains vulnerable to exogenous shocks--most importantly changes in external aid and in international commodity prices. 2.3 The modest economic growth achieved in the past five years has not significantly reduced poverty levels. Over half of the population remains poor and the poverty gap has widened. The modest growth level can in part be explained by a decade- long decline in the net accumulation of capital stock. While private investment has recovered it remains at a modest level of seven percent of GDP. Public investment has been relatively high--about ten percent of GDP--yet to a large extend, resources have been poorly allocated and invested inefficiently. 2.4 The new Government came into power in August 1993 and is committed to macroeconomic stability and a set of reforms intended to accelerate growth and reduce poverty. The Government has acted aggressively--and so far successfully-- to correct the fiscal equilibrium which emerged in 1993. The inflation rate has declined from 10 percent in 1993 to 8.5 percent at the end of 1994. While Government must continue to consolidate macroeconomic stability, the most crucial challenge remains to reduce poverty in light of the fact that approximately 70 percent of the total population lives under conditions of poverty. This challenge is even more pronounced in the rural areas where over 95 percent of the households are poor. B. The Rural Sector 2.5 The vastness of Bolivia's territory (1.09 million kMn2), and the cultural diversity of its population, encompassing several ethnic groups and languages, have shaped a society marked by sharp contrasts particularly evident in the rural sector. The Natural Resources Base. 2.6 National territory has three ecologically distinct regions: the Highland Plateau (Altiplano) in the west, the inter-Andean Valleys in the center, and the flat tropical Lowlands in the East. Highland conditions are especially severe with high risk of crop failures due to drought, hail and frost. The climate of the Valleys is milder. Much of the dense tropical forests of the humid tropical Lowlands have been cleared for agriculture or livestock grazing. 2.7 Good agricultural land, found mainly in valley bottoms, lake shores and alluvial plains, is scarce. In the Lowlands, large tracts suitable for livestock have extremely low population densities. Of the total cultivable land area (about five million ha), less than 40 percent is under crops in any given year. The balance is either left fallow to restore fertility, or used as grasslands. Forests and woodlands comprise roughly half the country's territory, and grasslands about one-third.
 - 3 - 2.8 While Bolivia is a sparsely populated country, with 6.5 inhabitants per km2, nearly 75 percent of the country's rural population live in the Highland Plateaus and the Valleys, representing 38 percent of the land area. This concentration has led to over- exploitation of natural resources, resulting in lost vegetative cover, accelerated soil erosion and declining soil fertility. 2.9 Impoverished conditions and limited alternatives have induced many, usually young, people of the rural Valleys and Highland Plateau to emigrate. Many move to the urban centers seeking improved employment opportunities and access to better public services. Others have resettled in the Lowlands. Still others have relocated, permanently but more often temporarily, to the tropical Valleys to work in coca production. As a result, while the rural population has stagnated (annual growth rate of 0.09 percent), the urban population has expanded at an annual rate of four percent; with the share of the rural population falling from 59 percent of the total population in 1976 to 48 percent in 1992. The Rural Economy 2.10 Agriculture is the primary economic activity for 80 percent of the rural families. Nearly four-fifths of these farm famnilies, especially those located in the Andean Ilighland Plateau and Valleys, engage in traditional farming. A capital-intensive sub- sector thrives in the tropical Lowlands. The agricultural sector accounted for a fifth of national GDP and employed 45 percent of the labor force in 1992. Legal agricultural exports have fluctuated between US$160 million and US$230 million over the last few years, representing between 20 and 25 percent of the country's export earnings. 2.11 Since 1987, real annual sectoral growth of 1.5 percent has originated almost exclusively from the modem export-oriented Lowland sub-sector, whose expansion is based on area increases for soybean production. In contrast, the traditional sub-sector has not responded to the recent adjustments in relative prices and has had negligible growth. Relatively high production and marketing costs, attributable to rudimentary technologies, poor market opportunities and a persistent absence of support services (especially roads and agricultural extension), have depressed the sub-sector's performance. 2.12 Traditional agriculture, providing 65 percent of the gross value of legal agricultural production, is conducted on small farms - all under five ha and most under one ha. Maize, potatoes, barley, and quinoa are the important crops. In addition, traditional farm families usually have a small herd of livestock, including llama, alpaca and cows. Traditional farmers use rudimentary technology, rely on family labor and make limited capital investments. As a result, for the past twenty years, crop yields have stagnated at very low levels. 2.13 In the Highland Plateau, traditional farming is practiced under harsh natural conditions, where frosts and droughts frequently threaten harvests. In the Valleys, where
 the climate is more favorable, there is some crop intensification under irrigation. In the tropical regions of the Valleys, small farmers produce coca. Throughout the sub-sector, weak infrastructure aggravates the dispersion of its population, impeding market development for produce, services and labor among sub-regions and with urban centers. 2.14 Having been largely by-passed by economic development and modernization, traditional farmers and indigenous peoples are among the country's poorest. Income derived from farm market sales does not cover the needs of most small farm families. Consequently, many households diversify their activities to include cottage industries, seasonal migration and petty commerce. Others send members to the cities to work as day laborers or domestics. Despite these additional income sources, incidence of rural poverty, measured in terms of satisfaction of basic needs', remains at 94 percent. 2.15 Modern agriculture, concentrated in the tropical Lowlands, is conducted by a rural elite with relatively large farms, ranging from 50 ha to tens of thousands ha. Production is geared towards agricultural and forest export commodities, mainly soybeans and timber, and some import substitutes. These enterprises are highly mechanized, raise livestock extensively and hold vast tracts of undeveloped land. In recent years, this sector has shown considerable dynamism and growth. Social Context 2.16 Vibrant and diverse indigenous cultures are fundamental characteristics of the rural sector. In the Highland Plateau, most of the population pertain to the largest indigenous group, the Aymara- and Quechua-speakers (2.5 million people). The Highland Plateau also encompasses the Chipayas and the Urus. People of the Valleys are of diverse ethnic origin, but generally speak Quechua. In the Lowlands, there are 26 indigenous groups, speaking at least fifteen different languages and comprising between 80,000 to 150,000 people. The indigenous Lowland people are actively defending their territorial claims against encroaching lumber companies and extensive livestock operations. Throughout the country, fragmentation of traditional structures emanating from pressures to survive in a rapidly changing national economic environment threaten the cultural identity of nearly all the indigenous people. 2.17 Rural society, across the ethnic groups, is composed of, and revolves around community organizations which carry out important communal social, economic and religious functions2 Any important community issue is decided by consensus in the assembly of heads of families of the community, ayllu, the community's highest decision- making authority. In most respects, allegiance to the ayllu and the community far exceeds that to any civil Government. The ayllu manages and distributes communal lands and resolves disputes among members and between other communities. Women are solely responsible for domestic affairs, including family nutrition, education and health. They provide child care, cultivate, process and prepare basic foods, care for small animals and market farm produce. Agricultural and manual labor is divided equally between the husband and wife. In addition, women make crafts and textiles providing a significant source of household income. 2.19 According to the 1992 Census, nearly one-quarter of rural households are headed by women. Households with women as heads are most prevalent in the Highland Plateau. In Chuquisaca, Potosi and Oruro, because of the high rate of emigration of men, more than one-third of poor rural households are headed by women. In the Tropics, women head households are less common, with less than 10 percent of the poor rural households headed by women. Female-headed households are among the poorest of the rural households as family income of those households is only 54 percent of the average income of households with both a male and female income earner. C. Rural Development Policy 2.20 In August 1993, upon assuming office, Government established five policy objectives: (i) privatization of public enterprises to stimulate private investment and public savings; (ii) employment generation; (iii) greater resource allocation to the public health and education systems; (iv) modernization of the Executive Branch; and (v) greater citizen participation in public decision-making through popular participation. Fundamental to these policies is the principle that the Bolivian people are to become protagonists in their own social and economic development which would eventually fully satisfy their basic needs through secure access to adequate incomes and good social services. 2.21 The most important rural sector policy goal is higher productivity, especially in the traditional sub-sector, through improved technologies, appropriate application of modern inputs and increased productive infrastructure investment. In addition, to introduce greater employment opportunities through the diversification of the rural economy, the policy promotes efficient non-farm economic activities and encourages urban-rural complementarities. Other important policy objectives are to ensure the rational use of natural resources and that prices remain undistorted, so that they continue to be efficient signals of market demands to producers. 2.22 Government proposes to address rural poverty alleviation and economic development through the incorporation of hitherto marginalized rural and indigenous communities into the country's political and economic processes and empower them 3 Ranaboldo, Claudia, Muier v Gest6n Ambiental en Bolivia, FONAMA, La Paz, 1993.

Government policy is referenced within a framework of three principles: (i) popular participation; (ii) respect for ethnic identities; and (iii) protection of the environment. The new approach is predicated on the premise that rural development can only succeed when it respects and is built upon the rural communities, their cultural identities and values. D. Rural Development Strategy 2.23 To achieve the policy objectives, Government strategy is to: (i) fully implement the participatory development process as outlined in the LPP; (ii) build the capacity of public institutions, especially municipalities, and private organizations to manage this process; (iii) identify, systematize, and prioritize local demand for rural investments to improve productive capacity; and (iv) provide the funds, mainly through matching grants, to respond to this demand while at the same time ensuring adequate technical capacity to implement the investments. Implementation of the Popular Participation Law 2.24 The LPP of April 1994, provides the legal rationale and impetus for the introduction and application of the participatory planning process. The rural development strategy supports the LPP by strengthening the rural communities so that they can define and direct their own sustainable development. The implementation of the rural strategy involves both public institutions and active non-governmental organizations (NGOs). The participation of NGOs is a critical determinant of successful implementation because of their extensive experience in working with rural communities. 2.25 The LPP organizes the rural sector into municipalities, so that every area, including those previously not serviced by any local government, belongs to a municipality. In doing so, the law not only created many new municipalities, but also vastly expanded the jurisdiction of existing municipalities. Besides creating a new administrative structure, the LPP explicitly recognizes traditional forms of organization and representation (Art. 3, LPP). In this context, the Regulation of the LPP (Art. 26-29) allows the formation of indigenous municipal districts within municipalities or a conjunction of indigenous municipal districts among various municipalities. These districts have the following characteristics: (i) their jurisdiction is related to ethnic population and their social organization; (ii) election and representation are based on traditional ways and means; and (iii) the maximum traditional authority assumes the functions of deputy-mayor (sub-alcalde). 2.26 The LPP calls for the decentralization of political authority and more equitable distribution of public revenues. It is a bold attempt to depart from a traditionally highly-centralized government structure, where fiscal allocations are subject to the discretion of national authorities, influenced by powerful interests. As a result, in the past, 90 percent of public funds went to the three major urban centers. Under the LPP, allocations of funds from the national treasury for the municipalities (Co-participation
 - 7 - Funds) are to be based exclusively upon the number of inhabitants. In principle, the share allocated to the rural municipalities would increase from less than 10 percent at present to approximately 50 percent of Co-participation Funds. The LPP stipulates that no more than 10 percent of these funds could be allocated to cover municipal administrative costs, with the remaining resources being earmarked for new investment, co-financing and maintenance costs. To receive the Co-participation funds, municipalities must submit annual operative plans and detailed municipal budgets to the central government. 2.27 For most municipalities the availability of co-participation funds means a considerable increase in revenue. Total co-participation funds available for distribution to all 301 municipalities in 1995 are estimated at US$145 million. Since the 98 municipalities included in the project area are relatively small in terms of population, co-participation funds available to those municipalities are estimated at approximately US$20 million in 1995 (see Annex 6 for details). Given actual disbursements of FDC and FIS at around US$50 million in 1994, it is clear that resources available to municipalities for financing investments are significant, even taking into account administrative expenditures and operation and maintenance costs to be paid from the municipal budget. 2.28 By virtue of the law, each community becomes a legal entity referred to as a Territorial Base Organization (Organizaci6n Territorial de Base, OTB). The OTBs select their official representative before the Municipal Council. Any grassroots entity, including a traditional community group, such as an ayllu or tribe, or a rural union (sindicato), or any individual, designated by the community, qualifies as a representative. The OTB can negotiate loan/grant agreements and service contracts and administer funds. The communities will also appoint a Supervisory Committee (Comite de Vigilancia--CV) to control the activities of the Municipal Council. 2.29 LPP specifies new and additional obligations for various public, civic and private institutions. The responsibility for health, education, irrigation and rural roads infrastructure, as well as their maintenance are to be transferred from the central to the municipal governments. Municipalities will also be responsible for property tax collection. 2.30 More importantly, LPP gives new responsibilities and authority to local institutions with respect to their social and economic development, outlining a demand- driven process for directing public development resources to the rural communities. This process begins with rural community members identifying, through consensus, investments necessary for their economic development. The communities draft a development plan, which their OTB representative submits to the Municipal Development Council. The Council coordinates and ranks funding solicitations of the various communities within its jurisdiction, and, with the OTBs' input, designs the Municipal Development Plan (Plan Municipal de Desarrollo, PMD).
 - 8 - Institutional Capacity Building 2.31 As part of its strategy, Government would strengthen those public institutions, especially SNDR, involved in disseminating and supporting the Participatory Planning Process (PPP). The PPP is a set of methodologies designed to facilitate community organizations (OTBs) in recognizing and articulating their goals and needs into development plans. Central to the PPP is the community diagnostic, a method relying on group dynamics which allows community members to focus on their assets, visualize goals and evaluate development requirements (see Annex 1). 2.32 To carry out the PPP the municipalities and the rural community organizations must be able to: (i) prepare municipal development plans; (ii) galvanize a consensus among members; (iii) present their plans to donor institutions for financing, and (iv) supervise and be held financially accountable for the projects. 2.33 While the rural sector has historically been composed of effective community organizations, few have had any experience in identifying, formulating and prioritizing their development investment needs and presenting them in formats acceptable for financing. Many rural organizations do not fully understand their new responsibilities as defined in the LPP. Others are neither technically nor administratively ready to assume these responsibilities. 2.34 Training programs would therefore be an important component of institutional capacity building. Effective implementation of participatory rural development requires training for: (i) municipalities; (ii) Executing Agencies (Entidades Ejecutoras, EE); and (iii) OTBs. All are important to ensure that the participatory process reaches the rural communities and that the communities are capable of responding to the challenges presented by the process. The objective of the training program is to transmit the precepts of Government's new rural development strategy to rural communities and provide the technical, managerial and administrative skills for the strategy's effective implementation. Training is described in Annex 7. 2.35 Government, with IDA support, has already conducted a pilot project in nine provinces and has been verifying the validity and appropriateness of the PPP methodology. As result of the findings of this pilot project, the PPP methodology is being adjusted to the particular social, economic and cultural conditions of the communities. Consequently, SNDR's regional representation would be strengthened by establishing new offices and increasing staff in existing branches. E. Institutional Framework Public Institutions 2.36 The following institutions have mandates relevant to this project: (i) the Ministry of Human Development (Ministerio de Desarrollo Humano, MHD) with the National Secretariat for Rural Development, and the National Secretariat of Ethnic,
 - 9 - Gender, and Youth Affairs; and (ii) the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment (Ministerio de Desarrollo Sostenible y Medio Ambiente, MDSMA) with its National Secretariat for Popular Participation. 2.37 The National Secretariat for Rural Development (Secretaria Nacional de Desarrollo Rural, SNDR) promotes integrated rural development through the participation of grassroots community organizations. Its programs are highly targeted to the rural poor. SNDR formulates rural development policies and facilitates the implementation of the PPP through organization, training, and empowerment of local institutions. In addition, it follows-up and facilitates the preparation and implementation of local investment projects based on results generated in the participatory planning process. In general terms, SNDR could be considered as government's outreach agency, which intermediates between rural communities and state. Annex 3 describes the role of SNDR in more detail. 2.38 The National Secretariat of Ethnic, Gender, and Youth Affairs (Secretaria Nacional de Etnias, Genero y Generaciones, SNEGG) safeguards respect for the diverse ethnic identities of indigenous people and their rights as collective units. While its mandate is not limited to any specific region, current activities of SNEGG focus on the territorial issues of the indigenous peoples in the Eastern Lowlands. In addition, SNEGG deals with social, legal and economic issues related to the status of women and youth. 2.39 The National Secretariat for Popular Participation (Secretaria Nacional de Participaci6n Popular, SNPP) developed the popular participation legislation and is now designing procedures and regulations for the law's implementation. SNPP would be responsible for the transfer of powers between the central and local governments. Through its departmental offices, SNPP is assisting with creation and institutional strengthening of municipalities, and formation and registration of OTBs. 2.40 The Regional Development Corporations (Corporaciones Regionales de Desarrollo, CORDES) are important players in the planning process as a recent Presidential Decree4 assigns to them a wide range of responsibilities concerning planning of Departmental investments, and strengthening of municipalities. In general terms, CORDES are expected to: (i) integrate municipal plans in a Departmental planning perspective; and (ii) ensure that allocation of resources in the Departments is in line with participatory planning at the micro-regional and sub-regional level. More specific relevant responsibilities include: (i) developing and maintaining Departmental databases including information on existing resources, development constraints, and investment opportunities; (ii) strengthening municipal capacity to implement PPP efforts, prepare PAOs, and manage natural resources; (iii) preparing and executing investment projects whose impact goes beyond the municipal level; (iv) preparing and executing local investment projects which are too complex to be handled by municipalities; (v) promoting and coordinating the 4 Decreto Supremo No. 23845. To coordinate the activities of the different Secretariats involved in the implementation of the LPP, an Inter-secretarial Committee was established on July 12, 1994, following "Resolucidn Biministerial No. 013/94". To more specifically coordinate the involvement of the Ministries of Human Development and Sustainable Development and Environment in the preparation of the Rural Communities Development Project, an inter-ministerial coordination-ordination program was established on July 15, 1994, following "Resolucd6n Biministerial No. 07/94. A draft agreement, prepared by the committee, indicates that SNDR, SNPP and the Regional Development Corporations (CORDES) agree that SNDR would take a leading role to implement the LPP in 98 municipalities included in the target area of project intervention, whereas the CORDES would have primary responsibility regarding this task in the other 205 municipalities. Funding Agencies 2.42 The Small-Farmer Development Fund (Fondo de Desarrollo Campesino - FDC) is an autonomous public institution financing rural development activities and investments. It was created in 1989 and operates under the Ministry of the Presidency (MP). According to a new structure, FDC has a Board composed of four Directors, appointed by the MP Minister and headed by a President nominated by the President of the Republic. In addition, there is a General Manager, appointed by the FDC Board, responsible for administration and operation. Within FDC, there are four divisions: (i) Infrastructure and Services; (ii) Credit; (iii) Administration and Finance; and (iv) Planning, Follow-up and Evaluation. 2.43 FDC is a financial intermediary, involved in project appraisal, approval, disbursement, and technical follow-up. Within the Investment Program for Small-Farmer Development (Programa de Inversi6n para el Desarrollo Campesino, PIDC), FDC finances, on a grant basis, initiatives up to a maximum of US$250,000 per project in: (i) basic infrastructure, including feeder roads, bridges, irrigation, markets, cottage industries, and protective structures; (ii) agro-support services, such as technical assistance and extension to farmers, revolving funds, and farm inputs; (iii) reclamation projects, like sub-watershed management and agro-forestry projects; and (iv) institutional strengthening for executing agencies and target communities. Beneficiary communities contribute in labor, kind or cash between 10 and 30 percent of the project costs. Lessons from Experience 3.6 Past Experience: Past development efforts in Bolivia were highly centralized, top-down and rarely met the real needs of the rural population. Experience from the IDA-financed Omasoyos-Los Andes Development Project and the Ulla Ulla Development Project shows that these centralized projects have been alien to the beneficiaries, administratively complex, costly to maintain and can not be sustained. Experience from pilot projects and isolated programs in Bolivia shows that successful development efforts tend to be those administered at the local level by NGOs or other groups close to the beneficiary communities. The experience of the past twenty years in Bolivia clearly indicates that effective rural projects have: (i) been relatively small and built upon existing traditional social structures; (ii) been designed, formulated and executed with considerable beneficiary participation; and (iii) have sufficiently taken into account the role of women in the household and the community, and have integrated women in the project development and implementation. 3.7 The 1993 Agriculture Sector Review concluded that: (i) local participation needed to be promoted to achieve greater relevance and efficiency in the design and implementation of public expenditure in rural areas; (ii) Governments should decentralize many of their functions to more local levels, and seek greater involvement of local communities, particularly in the design and management of public infrastructure projects in rural areas; and (iii) involvement of local communities should be sought through social and administrative arrangements that encourage and reward people's participation in public expenditure decisions.

Environmental Issues 3.12 Deforestation, soil erosion, water pollution and loss of natural habitat are key environmental problems. Annually, an estimated 50-60,000 ha are deforested because of farmer encroachment, road construction, migration and logging. Soil erosion, a consequence of deforestation, and overuse of land, affects about 35 percent of the total territory. Water pollution, caused by industrial waste discharge, especially from mines, poses serious health hazards to a wide cross-section of the population. Bolivia is also losing its unique flora and fauna resources, mainly as a consequence of deforestation, contraband trade, and migration to the Lowlands. Indiscriminate land clearing, road construction, poor management of land, water and forest resources threaten the sustainability of agriculture, forestry and biodiversity. The present Andean rural community structure is based upon the pre- Hispanic ayllu. During the colonial period, most ayllus where incorporated into the Spanish large properties (hacienda). In 1953, with the Agrarian Reform, sindicatos, local rural governments, were formed to transfer land from haciendas back to campesinos. 2. Today, the sindicato is found throughout the Andean region, co-existing with and complementing the ayllu. Sindicatos are part of a national network"3, a hierarchy which up to the provincial level, facilitates certain activities among comnmnunities. However, beyond the provincial level, the network serves national political interests and is vaguely related to the individual rural sindicatos. 3. Both sindicatos and ayllus require their members to be married and possess land. The head of the sindicato, the secretary general, is equivalent to the jilacata, the ayllu chief In many communities, the same individual holds both positions, acting as the jilacata, in ceremonial and traditional events, and, as the secretary general, in administrative and managerial affairs. The secretary general, along the with sindicato officers, are elected by the community for a one-year term. The appointment of the jilacata is based on a revolving principle used to encourage community participation. 4. Participation in the asamblea is one of the most important obligations of community members. At the asamblea, all significant decisions are taken through a tedious and time-consuming consensus process. In addition, members must elect community leaders, hold community office, assist in the execution of public works, and pay fees. In return, they have access to communal resources (land, water, construction facilities, etc.) and receive assistance from the community elders. 5. Andean communities have developed particular forms of cooperation between families and within the community. Families cooperate in major agricultural activities (sowing, harvesting and construction) through a system of reciprocity, whereby the support given by one family to another is recorded, and subsequently compensated by the recipient with even greater assistance. The approval of the LPP drastically changed the concept of the municipality as being primarily an urban center. Rural areas, whose administration used to be the exclusive responsibility of Departmental Governments assisted by Corporaciones Regionales de Desarrollo (CORDES), were added to the jurisdiction of existing municipalities or included in new municipalities. On average, a municipality consists of 40 communities, each legally represented by an OTB. OTBs directly supervise and control the implementation of municipal activities at the community level. They indirectly monitor and control municipal activities through a Comite de Vigilancia, which supervises the municipal budget. 2. Besides the creation of a new administrative structure, the LPP provides the legal framework for: (i) a major decentralization of political authority; (ii) a more equitable allocation of public revenues by the central Government; and (iii) increased local authority in local revenue raising. Consequently, ownership of physical infrastructure, including hospitals, primary and secondary schools, cultural and sport facilities, secondary roads; and micro-irrigation systems has been transferred to municipal Governments. Municipal Governments are now financially responsible for the administration and maintenance of existing physical infrastructure and supervise their operation. More importantly, new investments in these areas have to be financed from the municipal budget. 3. To allow municipal governments effectively assume their new responsibilities, the central Government increased the amount of public revenues allocated to municipalities, by making available so-called co-participation funds. These funds are allocated on a per capita basis. Actual disbursements only occur when an Annual Operative Plan (PAO) exists. Besides co-participation funds, municipalities are entitled to raise own revenues from land taxes and urban property taxes would directly benefit the municipal budget. This Annex describes briefly the sub-project cycle, eligibility criteria for sub-projects and beneficiaries, procurement and disbursement procedures. All procedures are or would become part of the FDC Operations Manual. The Sub-project Cycle 2. The processing procedures for eligible sub-projects consist of: promotion, identification, preparation, appraisal, approval, implementation, monitoring, acceptance of works (for infrastructure projects), operation, and ex post evaluation. 3. Promotion. FDC would participate in the training of NGOs and other executing entities (EE) to explain its programs and procedures. Moreover, FDC together with the EEs would inform municipalities and OTBs on: (i) the eligibility criteria for sub- projects; (ii) the processing steps for eligible sub-projects identified in their corresponding Development Plans, including sample documentation and approximate times of processing; and (iii) execution and supervision mechanisms applied by FDC. 4. Identirication. Under the project, FDC would process sub-projects included in municipal development plans, which may include eligible OTB development proposals and proposals from eligible executing agencies. All proposals should demonstrate community participation and consensus in the prioritization and identification of the sub-project. Proposals involving the use of resources that span outside the geographical coverage of the OTB or the municipality and where conflict may arise, should include the participation and agreement of the community(ies) affected by the proposed sub-project. 5. Preparation. The primary responsibility for sub-project preparation lies with the executing agency (which would include municipalities and OTBs). The preparation process may take one of three possible courses: (i) the sub-project is duly prepared according to FDC requirements and guidelines and requires no further work prior to appraisal by FDC; (ii) the sub-project profile complies with general eligibility criteria but requires FDC follow-up and feasibility studies; in such case, the executing agency would apply for financial assistance from FDC to contract out these studies to FDC-accredited professionals subject to prior assessment by the program officer on the compliance with basic eligibility criteria; and (iii) the sub-project profile does not meet sub-project eligibility criteria, requiring the executing agency to redesign it with guidance from the FDC program officer.
 - 88 - 6. Appraisal. The FDC program officer, seconded by specialists (consultants, CORDES staff or other), appraises the sub-project, including an environmental analysis. Any sub-project deemed unfeasible or not compatible with environmental standards may be rejected. The executing agency may then consider redesigning the sub-project and submit it again to FDC. 7. Approval. Sub-projects of up to US$80,000 are approved by the Finance Committee. Approval criteria includes economic returns, social impact, environmental impact and multiplier effect. Some sub-projects require further environmental analysis. Sub-projects of more than US$80,000 require ratification by FDC's Board of Directors. Approved sub-projects are then included in FDC's annual operating plan. 8. Implementation. The responsibility for sub-project implementation lies with the Co-operating Agency. Sub-project implementation rules include: (a) FDC signs a contract with the EC; (b) the EC enters into contract with the target community (if the target community is not an OTB eligible to act as EC); (c) the EC follows FDC bidding procedures; (d) the target community approves the hiring of external consultants/sub- contractors by the EC (for training and extension projects); (e) where applicable, the EC would enter into a contract with the construction contractor or supplier of goods or services submitting the successful bid; and (f) the EC would ensure proper project supervision as per its contractual obligations in (a). 9. Disbursement. FDC would make payments to ECs or directly to contractors and/or beneficiaries. Advances to ECs, contractors or communities are paid upon provision of a Bank Guarantee or against SOEs. The low technical and administrative capacity of many ECs, together with the weakness of FDC's Departmental offices, are two major causes of slow FDC disbursement. Most grassroots organizations have little experience in bidding procedures and have difficulties in providing Bank Guarantees, which is required by Bolivian law before the disbursement of any advance. FDC plans to set up a COTESU financed Guarantee Fund for ECs and beneficiaries to avoid this complex Bank Guarantee procedure. 10. Monitoring. The monitoring of the sub-project is shared by the executing agency, the beneficiary community and the FDC program officer in a pre-determined written arrangement. FDC has a planning, monitoring, and evaluation system detailing the specific instruments and the responsibilities of each. The implementation of this system requires a remarkable effort of the Departmental offices, which would be strengthened under the project. 11. Acceptance of Works. The responsibility for certifying due and proper fulfillment of conditions of the sub-project is shared by the EC, the beneficiary community and the program officer (if applicable, with the assistance of specialists at FDC headquarters and regional offices). All three parties issue an approval and formal certification of due and proper project sub-project performance.
 - 89 - 12. Operation, Maintenance and Ex-post Evaluation. The beneficiary community is primary responsible for sub-project operation. However, the EC would maintain a presence throughout the initial phase to ensure due and proper sub-project operation, provision of technical assistance services, maintenance and ex-post evaluation. Sub-project Eligibility Criteria 13. Under the project, the eligibility of sub-projects would be evaluated by FDC in accordance with its own procedures and would include the following criteria: (i) sub-projects must be identified by rural communities through a participatory process and be included in the municipal development plan; (ii) the technical feasibility of all the sub-project phases - from investment to operation- has to be attained; (iii) sub-projects must have a minimum Economic Internal Rate of Return of 12 percent; (iv) participation of women is included in the proposal; (v) sub-project design has to show the needed flexibility to answer future problems and to generate a multiplier effect; (vi) the environmental impact of the sub-project is to be evaluated and where necessary, environmental impact mitigation measures are to be proposed; and (vii) construction must take less than one year and not exceed US$250,000. 14. The economic evaluation of sub-projects is done on the basis of sub-project prototypes (proyecto tipo). FDC has estimated basic parameters for every sub-project prototype. These parameters are then adjusted to the actual sub-project, such as the number of beneficiaries and unit costs. 15. Typical sub-project would include basic infrastructure sub-projects, production support sub-projects and institutional strengthening sub-projects. Basic infrastructure sub-projects would not be eligible for financing by IFAD. Basic Infrastructure Sub-projects 16. Access Roads. The project would finance the rehabilitation and improvement of access roads linking remote communities in production zones to rural markets and feeder roads. Eligible access roads would be one-blade roads of a to 6 m wide (4 m in the hilly regions, 6 m in the Lowlands and highland plateaus) and complement the existing system of feeder roads of the National Road Service (Servicio Nacional Caminos, SNC). Construction of new roads and improvement of roads in environmentally sensitive areas such as forests, national parks and protected areas would not be financed. Costs should not exceed US$15,000 per km. 17. Bridges. The project would only finance bridges in areas where such investment solves an access problem, where the bridge complements a road access and
 - 90 - where the bridges would not create significant environmental problems . Vehicle bridges should not be more than 50 meters long and four meters wide, cost less than US$3,000 per meter (for vehicles) and US$1,000 per meter (for walkers)--total maximum FDC contribution would be US$150,000. 18. Small-Scale Irrigation. The project would finance small-scale irrigation schemes not exceeding US$250,000 per sub-project and US$2,500 per ha. Additional requirements would be that the beneficiary community owns the land and has access to roads for produce marketing. 19. Markets, Storage Centers and Artisanal Workshops. The project would finance infrastructure for markets, storage centers and artisanal workshops under the following rules: the land on which to build would legally belong to the beneficiaries; internal rules of the beneficiary communities provide systems to pay for operation and maintenance; markets would not cost more than US$100 per m2 covered; and (iv) FDC's maximum contribution would be US$50,000. Production Support Sub-projects 20. Rural Technical Assistance and Extension Services. The project would finance the demand from communities for rural extension services including the equipment and tools needed for the services. Services would include: technical assistance and training for farmers, livestock holders, natural resources management, agro-forestry, technology transfer, and assistance to produce marketing. Costs per sub-project should not exceed US$150 per sub-project beneficiary. 21. Revolving Funds for Agricultural Inputs. This type of FDC sub- projects would not be eligible for financing under the project. 22. Rural Experimental Activities. Maximum US$250,000 of the IFAD contribution could be used to finance small specific experiments and research activities including adaptive agricultural research in communities to experiment with new varieties and crops, agricultural processing and other similar activities. Each sub-project would not exceed US$25,000. Institutional Strengthening Sub-projects 23. Institutional Strengthening of the Beneficiary Community. The project would finance training of beneficiary communities through courses, seminars, workshops to interchange experiences between communities, contracting of technical assistance to improve the management and organization of the OTBs, and provision of tools and equipment to carry out the agreed activities. Under the IFAD component, FDC would also finance the instutional strengthening of co-operating agencies.

Sub- projects to improve integrated watershed management, forestry, pasture management, agricultural practices, etc., would generate a positive environmental impact. The training and capacity-building components would include sustainable natural resource management, thus generating a long-term benefits for the environment. The project, however, would implement sub-projects which may have some limited negative impact on the environment. Rural infrastructure such as improvements of access roads, small scale irrigation works, processing and marketing facilities, etc. could create localized environmental problems. The project would neither finance sub-projects related to opening of new roads, nor to road improvement in sensitive forest areas. The project would not finance sub-projects involving resettlement. 2. The Bolivian Environment Law (Ley 1333) requires that all sub-projects be carefully reviewed for environmental impact during feasibility studies and, when appropriate, mitigation measures be designed for implementation. The law makes a distinction between four categories of environmental impact. For Category I projects with strong environmental impact, a full environmental assessment has to be carried out. Such projects include activities with a wide national impact, important modifications in the characteristics of the environment, localization close to protected areas, forest zones and human settlements likely to be affected, resettlement of people, introduction of changes in the social, cultural and economic conditions of the people. Category II projects require a specific environmental analysis of those activities which may harm the environment. Category III projects may need to be conceptually reviewed to mitigate some particular minor environmental impact. Category IV projects have no impact on the environment and need not to be analyzed. 3. For each sub-project, EEs would complete an environmental evaluation form (Ficha Ambiental) which describes the sub-project's environmental impact. FDC's environmental unit would review the form and give it a provisional environmental category. FDC would send this information in bulk to the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment, responsible for the screening and which would review FDC's assessment on a sample basis. Under this project, no sub-projects of Category I would be financed. 4. Access Roads. The project would finance rehabilitation and spot improvement of existing roads, where the environmental problems have been tackled in the initial design. Building of new access roads would not be financed. Special

doc.abstracts: The Rural Communities Development Project will: (a) alleviate rural poverty by carrying out rural investments identified and formulated following a participatory planning process; (b) enhance the institutional capacity of the Secretariat for Rural Development (SNDR), the Small-Farmer Development Fund (FDC), and the Secretariat for Popular Participation (SNPP) to carry out the project; (c) improve the capacity of municipalities and rural communities to implement municipal development plans (PMD); and (d) strengthen non-governmental organizations (NGOs) assisting municipalities and rural communities in identifying, formulating and implementing rural investments and managing their PMDs.
